div.head: A Demarcation of the Thracian peraea of Thasos

p.seg:
A single boundary marker discovered (not in situ) at modern Petropege in Greece (not far from the putative site of Akontisma) attests to a Trajanic authoritative demarcation of a boundary “between the Thracians and the Thasians,” i.e., the boundary of Thasos’ well-attested peraea on the mainland of Thrace. The inscription invokes the auctoritas of the emperor and breaks off after the beginning of what appears to be a determinatio or a relative statement of distance along the boundary. Thasos’ peraea may have been the subject of a boundary dispute, attested by an inscribed letter of a Thracian governor sometime between AD 69-79. Instance
18 (Elliott 2004) . . There is no indication of a dispute in the present instance.
